description: From Middle English tart, from Old English teart (“sharp, rough, severe”), from Proto-West Germanic *tart, from Proto-Germanic *tartaz (“rough, sharp, tearing”), from Proto-Germanic *teraną (“to tear”), from Proto-Indo-European *der- (“to flay, split, cleave”). Related to Scots tairt (“tart; tartness”), Dutch tarten (“to defy, challenge, mock”), German trotzen (“to defy, brave, mock”), perhaps Albanian thartë (“sour, acid, sharp”).

entries.meaning: Sharp to the taste; acid; sour.
examples: I ate a very tart apple.

entries.meaning: (of wine) high or too high in acidity.

examples: He gave me a very tart reply.

description: From Middle English tart, tarte, from Old French tarte, tartre (“flat pastry”) (compare Medieval Latin tarta), of unknown origin. Perhaps an alteration of Old French torte, tourte, from Latin turta, perhaps from tŏrta f (“twisted”), in which case it would be cognate to torta.

entries.meaning: A type of small open pie, or piece of pastry, containing jelly or conserve; a sort of fruit pie.
A melt (block of wax for use in a tart burner).

description: From sweetheart or jam tart (“attractive woman”) by shortening.

entries.meaning: (Britain, slang, derogatory, by extension) Any woman with loose sexual morals.

verbs.description: tart (third-person singular simple present tarts, present participle tarting, simple past and past participle tarted)

entries.meaning: To dress garishly, ostentatiously, whorishly, or sluttily.
